qas.question: What can be used to prevent dehydration?
What are some good standard home solutions?

answers.text: salted rice water, salted yogurt drinks, vegetable and chicken soups with salt

qas.question: What is a commercial solution that can also be used?
What is the WHO's recipe for ORS?

answers.text: one liter water with one teaspoon salt (3 grams) and two tablespoons sugar (18 grams) added

plausible_answers.text: drinks with too much sugar or salt

qas.question: What can WHO be used for in children?

plausible_answers.text: salted rice water, salted yogurt drinks, vegetable and chicken soups with salt

qas.question: Can you name some plain water solutions?

plausible_answers.text: the same amount of sugar but only one-half a teaspoon of salt

qas.question: How much chicken soup does the Rehydration Project recommend adding?

context: <a0_0>Oral rehydration solution (ORS)<a0_0/> (a slightly sweetened and salty water) can be used <b5_0>to prevent dehydration<b5_0/>. Standard home solutions such as <a1_0><b6_0>salted rice water, salted yogurt drinks, vegetable and chicken soups with salt<b6_0/><a1_0/> can be given. Home solutions such as water in which cereal has been cooked, unsalted soup, green coconut water, weak tea (unsweetened), and unsweetened fresh fruit juices can have from half a teaspoon to full teaspoon of salt (from one-and-a-half to three grams) added per liter. Clean plain water can also be one of several fluids given. There are commercial solutions such as <a2_0>Pedialyte<a2_0/>, and relief agencies such as <b7_0>UNICEF<b7_0/> widely distribute packets of salts and sugar. A WHO publication for physicians recommends a homemade ORS consisting of <a3_0>one liter water with one teaspoon salt (3 grams) and two tablespoons sugar (18 grams) added<a3_0/> (approximately the "taste of tears"). Rehydration Project recommends adding <b8_0>the same amount of sugar but only one-half a teaspoon of salt<b8_0/>, stating that this more dilute approach is less risky with very little loss of effectiveness. Both agree that <b4_0>drinks with too much sugar or salt<b4_0/> can make dehydration worse.
